title: Kyle Edmund suffers sixth consecutive defeat, with Dan Evans set to replace him as British No 1
text:
Eighteen months after becoming British men's No 1 Kyle Edmund will be forced to hand over the status to someone who was still serving a ban when he first gained the top spot.

Next week Dan Evans is expected to become, officially, Britain's best player when Edmund - who went down to a sixth consecutive defeat on Monday - drops out of the world's top 50.

Edmund lost 6-4, 7-6 in the first round of the Shanghai Masters to Frenchman Jeremy Chardy, thereby guaranteeing that Evans will leapfrog him next Monday, even though the 29 year-old Midlander lost in the qualifying event this weekend in China.

Kyle Edmund is set to relinquish his status as the British No 1 after suffering a sixth loss in a row

Dan Evans is expected to officially replace Edmund as Britain's No 1 next week

Edmund has won only 12 tour matches in 2019 and has now suffered first-round exits at his last four tournaments, including at the US Open last month.

While Dan Evans, who lost in Shanghai qualifying, is set to leapfrog Edmund to become British No 1, Cameron Norrie also stands a chance after another win in China.

Qualifier Norrie beat experienced Frenchman Gilles Simon 7-5 6-2 but next faces a difficult test against US Open finalist Daniil Medvedev.

Edmund has won 12 tour matches in 2019 and has exited in round one in last four tournaments

Edmund's dismal form continued as he fell to a 6-4, 7-6 (3) loss to Frenchman Jeremy Chardy

Murray and Norrie could both theoretically deny him, although it is highly unlikely.

On leg three of his four week comeback trip on Monday Murray overcame a sluggish start to defeat world No 56 Argentinian Juan Ignacio Londero 2-6, 6-2, 6-3, with the Scot in a cranky mood until he asserted his superiority at the end.

It was his first win at Masters level since the Spring of 2017 and he now meets Fabio Fognini.

Norrie scored a good win, taking out French baseliner Gilles Simon 7-5, 6-2 and faces US Open finalist Daniil Medvedev.
